threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

attributes.magic: Bourne-Again shell script, ASCII text executable

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The script begins by defining several variables. The `lspath` variable is set to the path of the `ls` command, the `domain` variable is set to the decoded value of `Yi41TFt0T0M1Y29tS`, and the `mainurl` variable is set to the decoded value of `aHR0cDovL2IuOS05LTguY29tL2JyeXNqCg==`.

Next, the script checks if the `chattr` command is executable. If it is, the script moves it to a new location and renames it to `zzhcht`. If the `chattr` command is not executable, the script attempts to reinstall the `e2fsprogs` package and then move and rename the `chattr` command.

Once the `chattr` command has been moved and renamed, the script sets the `CHATTR` environment variable to the path of the new location.

The script then defines a function called `vurl`. This function takes a URL as its argument and uses the `exec` command to open a TCP connection to the host specified in the URL. The function then sends an HTTP GET request to the host and reads the response.

Finally, the script checks if the current user is root. If the user is root, the script downloads and executes a script from the `mainurl` variable. If the user is not root, the script downloads and executes a different script from the `mainurl` variable.
